title: Fluid pressure problems : r/AskPhysics - Reddit
body: A student places their finger over the top opening of the straw and lifts the straw vertically a distance d with the water in the straw staying in the straw. a. Enter an expression for the difference in pressure ΔP = PB - PA between points B and A of the water, in terms of d, the density of the water, ρ, and the acceleration due to gravity, g
readable_content:
- ltgenspartan (2017-12-08): Fluid pressure problems

Title correction 1 problem, not multiple.

A drinking straw is placed in a glass of water. A student places their finger over the top opening of the straw and lifts the straw vertically a distance d with the water in the straw staying in the straw.

a. Enter an expression for the difference in pressure ΔP = PB - PA between points B and A of the water, in terms of d, the density of the water, ρ, and the acceleration due to gravity, g.

I have tried entering qgh, as ρ really shouldn't matter, as I've done this many times as a kid with soda, so it would make sense to me that it doesn't matter what the fluid is, but am otherwise stumped.

- Nerull (2017-12-08): Density absolutely matters. A straw full of water and a straw full of mercury will produce very different results. You've probably heard pressure expressed in inches of mercury at some point - there's a reason they specify the fluid.
